Solving the Laplace Equation

Properties of the Laplace equation

Definition. The Laplace equation is defined as ∇2Φ=0\nabla^2\Phi = 0∇2Φ=0 for a scalar field Φ\PhiΦ, where ∇2\nabla^2∇2 is the operator known as the Laplacian.

Time for a few quick properties of this partial differential equation which should help us out a tiny bit!

Property 1. Linearity. If Φ\PhiΦ and Ψ\PsiΨ are both solutions to the Laplace equation, then any linear combination of the two λΦ+μΨ\lambda \Phi + \mu \PsiλΦ+μΨ for scalars λ,μ\lambda, \muλ,μ also solves the Laplace equation.

This is swiftly verified via the linearity of the Laplacian operator itself.

Expressed in differential form, the Laplace equation ppears as follows:

∇2Φ=∂2Φ∂x12+∂2Φ∂x22+...+∂2Φ∂xn2=0\nabla^2 \Phi = \frac{\partial^2 \Phi}{\partial x_1^2} + \frac{\partial^2 \Phi}{\partial x_2^2} + ... + \frac{\partial^2 \Phi}{\partial x_n^2} = 0∇2Φ=∂x12​∂2Φ​+∂x22​∂2Φ​+...+∂xn2​∂2Φ​=0

for a scalar field Φ\PhiΦ in Rn\mathbb{R^n}Rn.

It's natural to broadly conceptualize solutions to Φ\PhiΦ into one of either two types: types where the solution is symmetric - ∂2Φ∂xi2\frac{\partial^2 \Phi}{\partial x_i^2}∂xi2​∂2Φ​ is the same in every single direction xix_ixi​, and thus equals zero - and types where the solution is not, and the function has different second partial derivatives along the axes and symmetry is lost.

This leads us to the following property:

Radial symmetry and isotropic solutions

Property 2. Radial symmetry. If Φ\PhiΦ is solely a function of the radius rrr from the origin, e.g. in polar or spherical coordinates - Φ=Φ(r)\Phi = \Phi(r)Φ=Φ(r) - then Φ\PhiΦ is symmetrical about all the coordinate axes; thus, if we can guarantee that Φ\PhiΦ has second derivative zero about one of the axes, it satisfies the Laplace equation by default.

Definition. Call such a solution Φ=Φ(r)\Phi = \Phi(r)Φ=Φ(r) to ∇2Φ=0\nabla^2 \Phi = 0∇2Φ=0 isotropic: it has no preferred direction.

Using the expression for ∇2\nabla^2∇2 in spherical coordinates (or, for the 2D analogue, polar coordinates) leads to Φ\PhiΦ satisfying

1r2∂∂r(r2∂Φ∂r)=0\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r^2\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r}) = 0r21​∂r∂​(r2∂r∂Φ​)=0

in which the other two terms involving the other partial derivatives ∂θ\partial_\theta∂θ​ and ∂ϕ\partial_\phi∂ϕ​ are eliminated because Φ\PhiΦ is conveniently only a function of rrr. This is now an ordinary differential equation - one we can easily solve!

1r2∂∂r(r2∂Φ∂r)=0∂∂r(r2∂Φ∂r)=0r2∂Φ∂r=β∂Φ∂r=βr−2Φ=α−βr−1\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r^2\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r}) &= 0 \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r^2\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r}) &= 0 \\ r^2 \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r} &= \beta \\ \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r} &= \beta r^{-2} \\ \Phi &= \alpha - \beta r^{-1} \end{aligned}r21​∂r∂​(r2∂r∂Φ​)∂r∂​(r2∂r∂Φ​)r2∂r∂Φ​∂r∂Φ​Φ​=0=0=β=βr−2=α−βr−1​

for arbitrary constants α\alphaα and β\betaβ. Note that, in particular, solutions of the form Φ=βr\Phi = \frac{\beta}{r}Φ=rβ​, e.g. Φ=−GMr\Phi = -\frac{GM}{r}Φ=−rGM​, represent the gravitational and electrostatic fields we all know and love (with r=0r=0r=0 representing the point inside the point mass or point charge, where potential is not defined).

Caution! This solution is clearly undefined at r=0r=0r=0, and does not solve the Laplace equation at that point.

If instead we want Φ\PhiΦ to be radially symmetric in cylindrical coordinates - Φ=Φ(r)\Phi = \Phi(r)Φ=Φ(r) with r=x2+y2r = \sqrt{x^2+y^2}r=x2+y2​ and no zzz-direction - then Φ\PhiΦ is independent of zzz and thus has zero partial derivative in that direction. As such, we need only consider

∇2Φ=1r∂∂r(r∂Φ∂r)=0r∂Φ∂r=βΦ=α+βlog⁡r\begin{aligned} \nabla^2 \Phi = \frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r})&= 0 \\ r\frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial r} &= \beta \\ \Phi &= \alpha + \beta \log r \end{aligned}∇2Φ=r1​∂r∂​(r∂r∂Φ​)r∂r∂Φ​Φ​=0=β=α+βlogr​

for our solution. This solution is invariant along the zzz-axis and changes only in the xyxyxy-plane; as such, it is also a solution to the Laplace equation in R2\mathbb{R^2}R2. Importantly, while the spherically symmetric solution Φ=α−βr−1\Phi = \alpha - \beta r^{-1}Φ=α−βr−1 in R3\mathbb{R^3}R3 decays to α\alphaα asymptotically, this solution grows to infinity as r→∞r \to \inftyr→∞.

Monopoles and dipoles

Always two, there are. No more, no less.
-- Master Yoda

We move on to one final property of solutions to the Laplace equation which allow us to generate more isotropic solutions from a single isotropic solution:

Property 3. If Φ\PhiΦ is an isotropic solution to ∇2Φ=0\nabla^2 \Phi = 0∇2Φ=0, then the directional derivative of Φ\PhiΦ in the direction of any vector d\mathbf{d}d, ∇dΦ=d⋅∇Φ\nabla_\mathbf{d}\Phi = \mathbf{d} \cdot \nabla \Phi∇d​Φ=d⋅∇Φ, is also a solution to the Laplace equation.

Proof.

Using summation convention, we have

∇dΦ=di∂iΦ\nabla_\mathbf{d} \Phi = d_i \partial_i \Phi∇d​Φ=di​∂i​Φ

and as such

∇2(∇dΦ)=∇2(di∂iΦ)=∑j=1n∂j2(di∂iΦ)\nabla^2 (\nabla_\mathbf{d} \Phi) = \nabla^2(d_i \partial_i \Phi) = \sum_{j=1}^n \partial^2_j (d_i \partial_i \Phi)∇2(∇d​Φ)=∇2(di​∂i​Φ)=j=1∑n​∂j2​(di​∂i​Φ)

and if indeed Φ\PhiΦ is an isotropic solution to the Laplace equation, then in every direction ∂i2Φ=0\partial^2_i \Phi = 0∂i2​Φ=0; as Φ\PhiΦ can be assumed to be smooth and continuous, swapping the order of the partial derivatives results in

∑j=1n∂j2(di∂iΦ)=∑j=1ndi∂i(∂j2Φ)=0.\sum_{j=1}^n \partial^2_j (d_i \partial_i \Phi) = \sum_{j=1}^n d_i \partial_i (\partial^2_j \Phi) = 0.j=1∑n​∂j2​(di​∂i​Φ)=j=1∑n​di​∂i​(∂j2​Φ)=0.

If we were to construct such directional-derivative-bound solutions, our basic building block would be:

Definition. Denote the isotropic solution to Laplace's equation in R3\mathbb{R^3}R3 as the fundamental solution, or the unit monopole, if it has the property that the flux of its gradient out of a sphere of any radius is equal to one.

The flux of the gradient ∇Φ\nabla \Phi∇Φ has the convenient physical interpretation of being either gravitational flux (for Φ\PhiΦ equalling gravitational potential, where ∇Φ\nabla \Phi∇Φ is gravitational force) or electric flux.

Proposition. The fundamental solution in R3\mathbb{R^3}R3 takes the form Φm=−1/4πr\Phi_m = -1/4\pi rΦm​=−1/4πr, and the fundamental solution in R2\mathbb{R^2}R2 takes the form f=log⁡r/2πf = \log r/2\pif=logr/2π.

Proof

For the general isotropic solution Φ=α−βr−1\Phi = \alpha - \beta r^{-1}Φ=α−βr−1, consider the flux integral

∯S∇Φ⋅dS\oiint_{S} \nabla \Phi \cdot \mathbf{d S}∬​S​∇Φ⋅dS

over an arbitrary sphere SSS centered at the origin. Using the expression of gradient in spherical coordinates, we have

∇Φ=∂∂r(α−βr−1)r^=(βr−2)r^\nabla \Phi = \frac{\partial }{\partial r}(\alpha - \beta r^{-1})\hat{\mathbf{r}} = (\beta r^{-2})\hat{\mathbf{r}}∇Φ=∂r∂​(α−βr−1)r^=(βr−2)r^

which is always parallel with the normal vector to the sphere at every point. Thus, the flux integral simplifies to the sum of βr−2\beta r^{-2}βr−2 throughout the surface of the sphere, where it is constant; supposing that the sphere has radius ρ\rhoρ and thus surface area 4πρ24\pi \rho^24πρ2, we have

∯S=4πρ2⋅βρ−2=4πβ\oiint_S = 4\pi \rho^2 \cdot \beta \rho^{-2} = 4\pi\beta∬​S​=4πρ2⋅βρ−2=4πβ

independent of radius ρ\rhoρ, yielding β=1/4π\beta = 1/4\piβ=1/4π and thus the fundamental solution Φm=−1/4πr\Phi_m = -1/4\pi rΦm​=−1/4πr. The R2\mathbb{R^2}R2 case follows similarly.

The fundamental solution is also known as the unit monopole because it's a hypothetical representation of a single magnetic pole (north or south), existing independent of its counterpart and freely suspended in space; despite every mathematical indication towards their existence and despite scientists' best attempts at smashing three billion dollars' worth of funding to bits and pieces in the Large Hadron Collider, monopoles have never been found outside of physicists' wet dreams and in-between the arms of your mom at the epileptic strip club down the street.

Given this fundamental solution, we define

Definition. A dipole of strength d\mathbf{d}d - a pair of magnetic poles with opposite polarity, i.e. north and south, separated by a close distance and with large but opposite strengths - can be modelled by the Laplace equation solution ∇dΦm\nabla_\mathbf{d} \Phi_m∇d​Φm​, where Φm\Phi_mΦm​ is the fundamental solution as above.
